name: NPR
text:
People in the U.S. are getting coronavirus test results faster now than they were in the spring, a new national survey finds.

But researchers also found that Hispanic and Black Americans are waiting longer on average than whites.
https://t.co/6xHPJk8Kw6

name: NPR
text:
Channing Dungey, one of the top African American executives in Hollywood, was named chairman of the Warner Bros. Television Group. She will replace Peter Roth who is stepping down early next year.
https://t.co/IImyAVvqH6

name: NPR
text:
NEW: President Trump and Joe Biden will have their microphones shut off while the other speaks at the beginning of each segment in Thursday's debate, the organizing commission says.
https://t.co/F5kXGyZygx

name: NPR
text:
A health worker who goes door-to-door in India. A doctor who fled Afghanistan and works in a California testing unit. Iceland's top health official, who's also a former helicopter rescue doctor.

Meet 3 women playing a key role in fighting the pandemic.
https://t.co/3eiKz3vskE

name: NPR
text:
TSA screened more than 1 million travelers at U.S. airport security checkpoints Sunday — the most since the start of the pandemic — even as many parts of the U.S. see a surge in COVID-19 cases.
https://t.co/d3Yvy1hond

name: NPR
text:
President Trump has signed into law a bipartisan bill creating a 3-digit hotline for mental health emergencies. The FCC aims to have the number, 988, running by July 2022.

"This is a game changer," says one advocate.
https://t.co/xumimK2vaA

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking how the virus has affected individual members of Congress. Here's the latest.
https://t.co/m9aBfeUsAP

name: NPR
text: Although it's not as widely known in the U.S. as his adventure tales like White Fang and The Call of the Wild, Martin Eden is now regarded as one of Jack London's greatest achievements. https://t.co/vdfrADefyo

name: NPR
text:
Having good conversations — whether with strangers or with your best friend — is an art form.

Here are some tips to help you improve, from active listening to navigating those awkward silences.
https://t.co/B6jl4fe75e

name: NPR
text:
Starting next month, San Francisco will deploy new unarmed teams of professionals from the fire and health departments — not police officers — to handle most calls for people in a mental health or behavioral crisis.
https://t.co/8qvb4GofwD

name: NPR
text:
A new study suggests that bottle-fed infants around the world may be consuming more than 1.5 million particles of microplastics per day on average. But researchers urge people not to panic.
https://t.co/NKDI9ajJDb

name: NPR
text:
Since 2014, Richard Wang has called Major League Baseball games in Mandarin Chinese for fans in Taiwan.

When the pandemic delayed the MLB season, he had a chance to introduce Taiwan's professional baseball league to audiences around the world in English.
https://t.co/4XvQDZRA7m

name: NPR
text:
TSA reports that 6.1 million people passed through U.S. airport checkpoints between Oct. 12 and Oct. 18 — the greatest weekly traveler volume since the start of the pandemic.
https://t.co/1sZ0KBRmhO

name: NPR
text: Pastor Michelle Thomas rescued and restored a cemetery for enslaved people. The historical project became tragically personal for Thomas when her son drowned and became "the first African American person who was born free to be buried in this cemetery." https://t.co/M1lk6pq4zA

name: NPR
text: Honing their orchestral pop sound since high school, Gracie Coates' and Rachel Ruggles are perfect musical mates. For their Tiny Desk (Home) concert they performed from their New York City apartment. https://t.co/90NYftjEqB
